awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  From Turbulence to Weather and Climate: Unraveling the Multi-scale Nature of Dust and Sand Transport in the Atmospheric Boundary Layer
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of this research project is on the lifting of sand by the wind, known as saltation, and how it is portrayed by weather and climate models.  Wind-blown sand has direct impacts, such as forming dunes, but also secondary impacts when the sand particles impact and eject much finer dust particles.  These particles are known as mineral dust aerosols and are one of the major contributors to global particulate matter, which affects human health, weather, climate, ecosystems, atmospheric chemistry, and the hydrological cycle.  Current numerical models treat saltation as a uniform process, when studies have shown that saltation is actually driven by turbulent winds close to the surface and is highly intermittent.  The researchers plan to improve the representation of the saltation process through a combination of theory, field campaigns, fine-scale modeling (Large-Eddy Simulation) and global-scale (Earth System) modeling.  The work will involve four main tasks:  1) Linking the intermittency and intensity of sand transport to atmospheric turbulence, 2) linking atmospheric turbulence to the overall atmospheric boundary layer properties from weather and climate models, 3) developing an improved dust emission parameterization that accounts for turbulence-drive intermittency, and 4) testing the hypothesis that intermittency plays an important role in the timing and magnitude of dust events.

The broader impacts of the project will include societal and education & outreach components.  A successful completion of the project will result in an improvement to the Community Earth System Model (CESM) and other weather and climate models which should result in more accurate forecasts of weather and regional climate changes in dusty regions such as the southwestern US and North Africa.  Two graduate students will be trained during the project, and the students along with the lead researchers and a professional educator will collaboratively develop an educational module, based on wind erosion and turbulence, that addresses a range of national and state standards in the physical sciences.  The modules will be disseminated via a workshop for high school teachers and through a website that collects physics-based lesson plans.  The researchers and graduate students will also interact with high school students through guest lectures and participation in the Adopt-a-Physicist program.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to study the wind transport of sand and dust particles above non-vegetated surfaces such as deserts and dune fields. When the wind blows, large sand particles hop on the surface and smaller dust particles get “suspended” in the airstream being transported far from their emission location. The transport of sand is important in itself, but it also controls the emission of dust. Dust transport has important consequences for human health, and for weather, climate and ecosystems. The scope of the project included studies of the coupling between near-surface turbulent wind motions and sand transport, and the resulting vertical distribution of dust particles in the atmospheric boundary layer. The approach combined a field campaign in the coast of California and high-fidelity numerical simulations of particle transport by wind motion using a hierarchy of approaches. 

The main outcomes of the present research are listed below:

1)     We have collected an unprecedented data set consisting of simultaneous high-frequency measurements of wind turbulence and sand fluxes using a 10m mast deployed in Oceano, CA. This data set is explored in one of the papers listed below (and in several manuscripts still in preparation), and it will be very useful for the community in developing and validating future models and theories of turbulence-saltation interaction.

2)     We have developed a new theory relating the vertical profiles of particle concentrations in the atmospheric surface layer to the surface fluxes. The theory is valid above dust sources (e.g. deserts) and sinks (e.g. oceans). We have used detailed large eddy simulations (LES) to show that the assumptions required in the development of the theory hold, and that the predictions are accurate for a range of particle sizes and atmospheric stability conditions.

3)     Also based on LES results, we have extended the theoretical model to the entire atmospheric boundary layer (ABL). This study was more focused on sea spray aerosol in the marine boundary layer, but it is equally applicable to dust over deserts. The theoretical model can reliably predict total aerosol loading and its vertical distribution within the boundary layer, and it will likely find many applications when coupled to weather and climate models.

4)     We have developed a better understanding of the effects of particle inertia in the vertical transport of small particles such as dust, sea spray, or snow in the atmospheric boundary layer. This effect has always been considered negligible for particles smaller than 20 or 30 mm. However, our direct numerical simulation results showed that the large increase in the turbulent kinetic energy dissipation near the ground gives rise to a shallow layer (typically a few meters deep) in which inertia is important. We termed this layer the inertial resistance layer, and showed that its existence may have important practical consequences in connecting surface emission fluxes to dust loading in the ABL.

5)     We developed better understanding of the interaction between wind turbulence and sand saltation flux near the ground, which will be useful in developing better parameterizations of saltation and dust emission for weather and climate models.

6)     We have developed a new approach to simulate ABL flows. This is based on an existing one-dimensional stochastic model of turbulence, which we have extended to include effects of atmospheric stability and interaction of plant canopies near the ground. This model can be used as a stand-alone model to produce fast calculations of turbulence statistics in the ABL, or it can be coupled to large-scale atmospheric models to provide more detailed description of interaction with the surface.

7)     So far, a total of 5 journal papers were produced and a number of presentations were given in conferences by the principal investigators and graduate students involved.

8)     This project created opportunity for training of two Ph.D. students and one postdoctoral fellow.

 

Papers resulting from this award thus far: 

L.S. Freire, M. Chamecki and J.A. Gillies (2016), “Flux-profile relationship for dust con- centration in the stratified atmospheric surface layer”, Boundary-Layer Meteorology, 160, 249–267.

D. Richter and M. Chamecki (2018), “Inertial effects on the vertical transport of suspended particles in a turbulent boundary layer”, Boundary-Layer Meteorology, 167, 235–256.

L.S. Freire and M. Chamecki (2018), “A one-dimensional stochastic model of turbulence within and above plant canopies”, Agricultural and Forest Meteorology, 250-251, 9–23.

R.L. Martin, J. Kok, T. Barchyn, C. Hugenholtz, M. Chamecki, and J.T. Ellis (2018), “High- frequency measurements of aeolian saltation flux: Field-based methodology and applications”, Aeolian Research, 30, 97–114.

I.D. Nissanka, H.J. Park, L.S. Freire, M. Chamecki, J.S. Reid, and D.H. Richter (2018), “Parameterized concentration profiles for aerosols in the marine atmospheric boundary layer”, Journal of Geophysical Research – Atmospheres, 123, 9688–9702.
